title: Requires building developments comply with present law or with satisfactory traffic control and street improvement plans in N.Y. city
summary: Requires that before a certificate of occupancy can be issued for a building located in a development in a city having a population of one million or more, present law respecting mapped street improvement and access thereto be complied with, or city planning commission must have certified, pursuant to requirements of a special purpose district set forth in city's zoning resolution, that development complies with a satisfactory plan of traffic control and vehicular access, and abutting street improvement satisfactory to department of transportation of the city.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2297

TITLE OF BILL:
An act to amend the general city law, in relation to requiring in a city
having a population of one million or more, that building developments
either comply with present law respecting abutting mapped street access
or, pursuant to requirements of a special purpose district set forth in
zoning resolution, comply with satisfactory traffic control and street
improvement plans providing vehicular access

PURPOSE OF BILL:
This bill will provide that if the city planning commission certifies
pursuant to a special zoning district set forth in such city's zoning
resolution that a development has adequate vehicular and emergency
access to a street or highway duly placed. on an official map or plan,
such certification shall satisfy the requirements of GLC §36(2).

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
This bill would allow the city planning commission certification in
certain special zoning districts to satisfy the requirements of GLC
36(2) concerning a development's access to a mapped street.  Currently,
in certain special districts the New York City Zoning Resolution
("NYCZR") requires that the New York City Planning Commission ("CPC")
certify that a development has adequate vehicular access. However, this
certification is not effective to satisfy the requirements of GLC
36(2) and a separate proceeding before the New York City Board of Stand-
ards and Appeals ("BSA") is required before the Department of Buildings
("DOB") can issue a certificate of occupancy for any development which
does not have direct access to a mapped street.

JUSTIFICATION:
This amendment is designed to eliminate the duplication of administra-
tive procedures that occurs when a developer is required to obtain both
a certification from the city planning commission that a development has
adequate vehicular access under requirements set forth in the zoning
resolution and a variance or special exception from the board of appeals
In order to obtain a certificate of occupancy for such development under
the GLC § 36(2).

BACKGROUND:
GLC § 36(2) is designed to ensure that all new buildings have reasonable
access to mapped streets for emergency and other vehicular access.
Under the provisions of GLC § 36(2) as historically interpreted in New
York City, any development which does not have direct access to a street
or highway shown on the official city map has been required to obtain a
variance from the BSA before the DOB will issue a certificate of occu-
pancy for any of the buildings located in the development. In granting
this variance, the BSA examines whether the development has adequate
emergency and vehicular access to a mapped street and imposes any neces-
sary conditions required to ensure such access.

BSA variances pursuant to GLC §36(2) have been prevalent in Staten
Island where there are many areas and neighborhoods which do not have
streets placed on the official city map. Typically, in these areas
streets were plotted by surveyors earlier in the century but never
placed on the official city map ("streets of record"). Many of these
streets of record have been improved and serve existing residences.  In
addition, many of these streets are shown on unofficial city maps and
plans, including the NYCZR. However, any development constructed on
these streets is not considered to have direct access to a street placed
on the official city map. Therefore, a variance is required from the
BSA. At the same time, as part of the general development review for
certain special districts in Staten Island, the CPC has required that a
developer obtain a CPC certification that developments have adequate
vehicular access. In making such a certification, the CPC examines the
development's overall access to a street or highway placed on the city
map and access and egress for emergency traffic in particular.

This act will provide that in special zoning districts where a CPC
certification concerning a development's vehicular access is required,
such certification would be sufficient to satisfy the requirements of
GLC §36(2). The act will have a limited effect because it will only
apply in those special zoning district instances when a developer ordi-
narily would be required to obtain both the CPC certification and a BSA
variance. In such cases, this act will eliminate the duplicate CPC and
BSA review procedures. The current dual procedure provides no public
benefit and greatly increases the processing time and expense for many
proposed developments, particularly in Staten Island. Because the major-
ity of such developments are residential developments, the cost of hous-
ing is adversely affected by the dual application process. For the
purpose of GLC §36(2), the CPC certification in certain special zoning
districts will provide adequate assurance that a development provides
the necessary access for vehicular and emergency traffic to a mapped
street.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
Immediately.
